Good information but it irks me a bit when people say that an organism develops something in order to accomplish something. In this case she says why they have this armor is for protection. But that isn't exactly how it works. The armor is a factor for their continual survival, yes, but that is just a byproduct of their development. There is no why in chemical or physical processes. There are developments and the advantages or disadvantages that come from it. Of course, the exception is if an organism deliberately intends to do something. Like why do apes, humans in this case, gather in groups. That is a deliberate process. It may seem ridiculous to bring this up but I do think it is important to paint as accurate a picture as possible about the processes that make up reality. It is a subtle yet important difference to make.

Its normal snails which happened to come into existence near a thermal vent. They absorb/intake the minerals its spewing. Most the snailscan, others not so much (metals) their bodies try to excrete them. Which through its excretion and location it solidifies on its feet (their words not mine). Then it continues to excrete them but can't in same spot, so they overlap into overlapping plates.

Could it be an accidental adaptation? It’s possible that for whichever process snails use to create their shells, Iron either replaces some of the minerals in the process or works even better than the replaced mineral. Maybe all snails would start creating armoured shells with enough iron present, or maybe these ones simply had to make do with a more abundant mineral instead and all the ones that couldn’t utilise the iron nearby died out.

It's not as surprising as it may seem, as it has been known for decades that the radula (that's a kind of a tongue) of several snails is hardened by incorporating Magnetite (Fe3O4) crystals. So pretty much the same as here, but on a much lower scale (armor) ... sorry for the pun
On the other side are Iron-Sulfides(next to Iron-oxides) the typical form, how Fe is stored within animal bodies (including humans).
